summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) employee at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York on August 5, 2021. The interview is part of the OIG investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein and surrounding circumstances. The agents question the BOP employee about procedural matters related to inmate transfers and counts, specifically regarding inmates Efrain Reyes and Fernandez, and about key accountability systems at the MCC.

events.title: Transfer of Efrain Reyes
events.description: Inmate Efrain Reyes was transferred from the MCC to a GEO private prison based on emails from the U.S. Marshal Service. He was listed as 'pre-removed' on the daily log at 0838 hours.

events.title: Move of Inmate Fernandez to Dry Cell
events.description: Inmate Fernandez was moved from the SHU to R&D and placed in a dry cell around 3:00 p.m. after a contraband incident during a visit. The system update for his location was not done immediately.

events.title: Overnight Count Discrepancy
events.description: A count sheet printed at 12:35 a.m. showed a discrepancy: the electronic system (SENTRY) indicated 72 inmates, while the paper count slip signed by M. Thomas and Noel indicated 73 inmates.

events.title: OIG Supplemental Interview
events.description: DOJ OIG agents conducted a voluntary, sworn interview with a BOP employee at the MCC to clarify procedural details related to inmate movements and counts from August 2019.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York, New York
keyFacts: The interview is part of the official DOJ OIG investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein and surrounding circumstances at the MCC.
Procedural details about inmate transfers were clarified: 'WAB' (With All Belongings) on a call-out list indicates an inmate is leaving the institution and not returning.
The interview reveals potential issues with inmate tracking: the system update for inmate Fernandez's move to a dry cell was not done immediately, which could lead to a 'bad count'.
The 'call-out' list for inmate movements is created in the SENTRY system, printed, and disseminated, but is typically deleted and recreated daily, making historical records difficult to obtain.
The BOP uses a 'chit' (C-H-I-T) system for key and equipment accountability, not a sign-out log. Each officer has personalized chits they exchange for equipment.
